title: Chinese Government provides RMB 141.7 million grant from National Assembly Building Rehabilitation Project (Linked to Project ID#12382)
description: Gabon's National Assembly Building (also known as Palais de l'Assemblée nationale or Palais Léon Mba) was constructed between May 1997 to August 30, 1999 with interest-free loans from the Chinese Government. Then, it was burned down by protesters in 2016 following allegedly fraudulent elections.   On December 7, 2016, the Chinese Government and the Government of Gabon signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed grant funding for the National Assembly Building Rehabilitation Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce committed RMB 141.762 million (or approximately 14.5 billion CFA) of grant funding. The project, which is being co-financed by the Gabonese Government, involves the demolition and reconstruction of the hemicycle within the National Assembly building, an extension of the building's capacity to accommodate more than 960 places (including 143 deputies), the rehabilitation and decoration of 205 offices, and the reconstruction of a fire pump room and a fire tank.   Jiangsu Jiangdu Construction Group Co., Ltd. is the contractor responsible for implementation. An implementation agreement was signed on June 12, 2018. Then, a groundbreaking ceremony took place on June 18, 2019. The project was originally expected to reach completion by August 2020. However, due to the COVID-19 epidemic, it was temporarily suspended. Project implementation resumed in the fall of 2020. The project was ultimately completed and handed over to the local authorities on June 14, 2021.

title: China’s Ministry of Commerce provides RMB 300 million grant for International Conference Center Construction Project in Gambia
description: In 2016, shortly after resuming diplomatic ties, the Chinese Government and the Government of Gambia signed an RMB 300 million grant for the International Conference Center Construction Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce was the source of funding. This project involve the construction of an international conference center — within Bijilo National Park near the Atlantic Ocean — with a floor area of 14,000 square meters, a 1,000-seat major conference hall, four 200-seat themed meeting rooms, one lounge, four pressrooms and news centers, 14 meeting rooms, office sections, banquet halls, and other accessory rooms. China Jiangsu Provincial Construction Company Ltd., a state-owned company, was the contractor responsible for implementation.  The project commenced on August 30, 2017, and a formal groundbreaking ceremony was held on September 14, 2017. During the Ceremony, Ambassador Zhang Jiming, the Chinese Ambassador to the Gambia, gave a speech emphasizing the project as a new milestone in deepening and developing bilateral relations.  On March 14, 2018, Ambassador Zhang Jiming and Minister of Transportation, Engineering and Infrastructure Qiao Bei co-chaired the third inter-departmental coordination meeting at the Gambia International Conference Center project. Both parties evaluated, communicated, and coordinated the implementation process of the project, and expressed satisfaction with the progress of the project and the efficient cooperation between the teams of the two countries. On July 4, 2018, Ambassador Zhang Jiming and Minister of Transportation, Engineering, and Infrastructure Chobe visited the project site and co-chaired the fourth inter-departmental coordination meeting. As of that meeting, the construction of the project was progressing steadily, and the main structure would be completed in the near future and enter a new construction phase. On August 11, 2018, Ambassador Zhang Jiming, went to inspect the project site, listened to the report of the person in charge of the project implementation and management unit, inspected key parts of the project on the spot, and emphasized that the project is a flagship project of pragmatic cooperation between the two countries. On September 30, 2018, Ambassador Zhang Jiming and Minister of Transportation, Engineering and Infrastructure of the Gambia Joe Bey visited the project site and co-chaired the fifth inter-departmental coordination meeting. .  As of January 8, 2019, the main structure of the conference center was complete, and the project has entered a second phase (involving decoration).   On March 7, 2019, President Barrow of the Gambia went to the project site for an on-site inspection. Ambassador Ma Jianchun, Minister of Engineering Chobe, Government Cabinet Secretary Cisse, Presidential Press Director Hisarho, etc. accompanied him. President Barrow first listened to the report on the basic situation and progress of the project from the project implementation unit, the person in charge of the management unit, and the representative of the Gambia Engineering Department, and then inspected the construction site. On July 31, 2019, Ambassador Ma Jianchun and Gambia Engineering Minister Chobe co-chaired the seventh inter-departmental coordination meeting for the project.   The project was completed on October 15, 2019, and the conference center was officially inaugurated on January 11, 2020. In honor of former Gambian President Dawda Kairaba Jawara, the conference center was named the Dawda Kairaba Jawara International Conference Centre. The handover ceremony of the aid-to-Gambia International Conference Center project was held at the Bijiro project site in Guangxi Coast. Gambia President Barrow, Vice President Toure, National Assembly Speaker Denton, Minister of Foreign Affairs Tangalla, Minister of Engineering Chobe and other cabinet members, some members of Congress, some envoys in Gambia, representatives of international agencies in Gambia, and construction units of Chinese projects, Management units, representatives of Chinese-funded institutions in Gambia and medical aid teams in Gambia attended the event, and nearly a thousand other people attended as well.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Dawda Kairaba Jawara International Conference Centre Construction Project. The Chinese project title is 冈国际会议中心项目 or 冈比亚国际会议中心项目.In email correspondence with AidData, Government of Gambia officials identified the face value of the grant that supported this project as $50 million. However, given that most large grants from the Chinese Government are denominated in RMB, AidData relies on the RMB 300 million estimate reported by the Chinese Government.

title: Chinese Government provides a RMB 60 million grant — via an ETCA — for the Mental Health Infrastructure Project (Linked to Project ID#67710)
description: On June 3, 2016, the Chinese Government and the Government of Georgia signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), in which the Chinese Government committed RMB 60 million in grant funding for the Mental Health Infrastructure Project. The funds were provided by the Chinese Government via China Development Bank (CDB). The Chinese Government had previously provided a RMB 30 million grant to improve Georgia's mental health infrastructure in 2014, as captured by linked project ID#67710.  The grant was intended to allow Georgia's Ministry of Internally Displaced Persons from the Occupied Territories, Health, Labour and Social Affairs to develop and improve the country's mental health infrastructure. More specifically, the grant proceeds were to be used by the ministry to help improve Georgia's health infrastructure by introducing outpatient and inpatient and crisis intervention services, as well as a psycho-social rehabilitation department for children and adolescents.  On January 11, 2018, the Chinese Government and the Government of Georgia signed an exchange of notes related to the implementation of the Mental Health Infrastructure Project. The project was ongoing as of June 17, 2019; the Government of Georgia, the Chinese Embassy, and a Chinese construction company were discussing the implementation of the project, specifically, the selection of the project site and the design process.

However, this very likely reflects the fact that MOFCOM disbursed the loan through a bank account that the borrower established with China Development Bank.

title: ICBC provides $88.13 million loan for Phase 1 of Rural Electrification in 5 Regions Project (Linked to Project ID#73197, #92023)
description: On December 29, 2015, Ghana's Parliament approved a $90,472,385 term loan facility agreement with the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) for Phase 1 of the Rural Electrification in 5 Regions Project. The loan agreement was countersigned by the lender and borrower on June 28, 2016. The loan, which is captured via Project ID#52991, carries the following borrowing terms: a 15.5 year maturity, a 4 year grace period, an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR plus a margin of 0.5%, a default (penalty) interest rate of 2%, a commitment fee of 1%, and a management (upfront) fee of 1.5%. The final maturity date of the loan is December 28, 2031.   China Export & Credit Insurance Corporation (Sinosure) provided buyer’s credit insurance for this loan, and when the upfront (lump sum) premium was reduced from its original estimate of $8,022,385 (as approved by Ghana’s Parliament on December 29, 2015) to $5,682,722.24, the face value of the loan was reduced to $88,132,722.24 (from its original value of $90,472,385) through a June 30, 2017 addendum to the June 28, 2016 facility agreement. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to partially finance a commercial (EPC) contract with China International Water and Electric Corporation (CWE), which was signed on April 11, 2016. The loan’s (principal) amount outstanding was GHS 235,660,000 ($42,082,142) as of December 31, 2020 and GHS 432,600,000 ($83,192,307) as of December 31, 2021.  Then, on August 12, 2020, the Government of Ghana and the Bank of China and ICBC signed a $95,375,020.36 loan agreement to finance Phase 2 of the Self-Help Electrification Project (SHEP) in 5 Regions. ICBC's contribution is captured via Project ID#73197 and BOC's contribution via Project ID#92023. The loan carries the following (estimated) borrowing) terms: a 15 maturity, a 4 year grace period, an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR plus a margin of 1.95%, a 0.5% commitment fee, and a 1.5% upfront (management) fee. The face value ($95,375,020.36) of this loan is inclusive of an estimated, upfront Sinosure insurance premium of $7,825,020.36. The loan’s (principal) amount outstanding was GHS 79,880,000 ($14,264,285) as of December 31, 2020 and GHS 442,900,000 ($85,173,076) as of December 31, 2021.  The purpose of the Rural Electrification Project in 5 Regions is to supply electrical materials and equipment for the electrification of 1,033 communities in the Ashanti, Brong Ahafo, Eastern, Volta, and Western Regions. It is being implemented in two phases and China International Water and Electric Corporation (CWE) is the contractor responsible for implementation of both phases. Phase 1 sought to connect 495 communities in 15 districts within the Ashanti Region, Eastern Region, Western Region, and Volta Region to the national electricity grid. This phase is now complete and it succeeded in connecting 507 communities to the national electricity grid. Phase 2 seeks to connect 582 communities in the Brong Ahafo Region, Ashanti Region, Eastern Region, Western Region, and Volta Region to the national electricity grid.  There are some indications that the ICBC loan for Phase 1 of the Rural Electrification in 5 Regions Project may have financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. According to the World Bank’s International Development Statistics, the Government of Ghana had accumulated principal and interest arrears to one or more official sector Chinese creditors worth $908,337,346.70) in 2020 ($763,228,526.60 in principal arrears and $145,108,820.10 in interest arrears). There are some indications that the China Eximbank loan for Phase 1 of the Kpong Water Expansion Supply Project may have financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. According to the World Bank’s International Development Statistics, the Government of Ghana had accumulated principal and interest arrears to one or more official sector Chinese creditors worth $908,337,346.70) in 2020 ($763,228,526.60 in principal arrears and $145,108,820.10 in interest arrears). Then, on December 19, 2022, the Government of Ghana announced a sovereign default, suspending debt service on its Eurobonds, its commercial loans, and most of its bilateral loans.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Phase 1 of the Rural Electrification Program in 5 Regions and the Phase 1 of the Self-Help Electrification Project (SHEP) in 5 Regions. The Government of Ghana also refers to this project as the Rural Electrification Programme CWE. 2. The loan (facility) agreement can be accessed in its entirety via https://www.dropbox.com/s/dsfrstxc1uytmpz/90.4%20million%20ICBC%20loan%20agreement%20with%20Government%20of%20Ghana.pdf?dl=0. A summary of the June 30, 2017 addendum to the loan (facility) agreement can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/vb5ktnjas0x1psn/88%20million%20ICBC%20addendum%20to%20the%2090.4%20million%20ICBC%20loan%20agreement%20in%202016.pdf?dl=0. 3. The (principal) amounts outstanding are drawn from the Ghanaian Ministry of Finance’s Annual Public Debt Reports. These amounts are reported in GHS by the Ministry of Finance.
